articles.title: About
articles.contents:
Data graphics
I started doing data visualization work with an engineering education research group around 2008 and haven’t stopped. The iterative process we developed to “find the story” in our data has been instrumental in shaping my approach to data graphics. You can read more about our research at https://midfield.online/.
I occasionally write about visual rhetoric, graph design, and R on my Data Stories blog. Our day 3 case study is built on one of those essays.
Music
My dad was a guitar player and taught me my first chords. I’ve been songwriting and performing since my teens. A favorite musical pilgrimage is the annual Swannanoa Gathering near Asheville, NC in late July. I’ve posted some draft tracks to SoundCloud.
Work life
I am a graduate of California State University, Northridge (1991), and the University of Washington (1993, 1995). I taught mechanical engineering courses at Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology from 2000-2020. I retired from teaching in 2020. I also spent some years in industry, primarily in consulting engineering in Anchorage, AK, and Simi Valley, CA, with shorter stints at aerospace firms in Redmond, WA and West Palm Beach, FL.

articles.title: Data stories workshop
articles.description:
Extend your graphical repertoire and 
enhance your ability to tell stories with data.
articles.contents:
Welcome
The workshop has three sessions focusing on different aspects of storytelling with data.
Session 1: Limitations of common graph types
In the first session we demonstrate avoiding the perceptual limitations of common graph types to
Improve perception of stories in the data
Make it easier to reason quantitatively about the data
Thereby enhancing our credibility with the audience



Limitations of common graph types

Session 2: Expanding your graphical repertoire
In the second session we illustrate a repertoire of graph types and how they are suited to specific data structures. The session should encourage you to:
Understand the structure of one’s data
Explore different graph types suited to the data.
Keep reading and learning—an unfamiliar design may be just what you need.



Expanding your graphical reprtoire

Session 3: Critical thinking about visual information—a case study
In the third session we study the visual rhetoric of a deliberate visual lie in the pursuit of restricting reproductive rights. We focus on
How the authors abuse the conventions of visual rhetoric to serve their rhetorical goals
What legitimate stories these data tell
What legitimate questions the data raise



Critical thinking about visual information

Contact
